--- title: "3.2 — Marginal Productivity Theory — Class Content" execute: freeze: auto --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"} # Meeting Dates *Tuesday, October 25, 2022* ::: ::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"} # Assignments Due Your [1st short paper](assignments/01-short-paper) on the Classical Era is due Friday October 28 by email. ::: ## Overview Today we continue the marginalist revolution. ## Readings ### Required Readings - Ch.9 "The Transition to Neoclassical Economics: Marginal Analysis Extended" up to Profits and Interest (p.260) in Landreth & Colander - Ch.11 "Marginal productivity and factor prices" in Blaug ### Recommended Readings: The following Wikipedia entries can also provide more background: - [ Friedrich von Wieser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_von_Wieser) - [ Eugen von Böhm-Bawerk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eugen_von_Böhm-Bawerk) - [ John Bates Clark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Bates_Clark) - [ Phillip Wicksteed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phillip_Wicksteed) - [ Francis Ysidro Edgeworth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Ysidro_Edgeworth) - [ Knut Wicksell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knut_Wicksell) ### Questions to Help Your Reading - How are the prices of factors of production (land, labor, capital, etc) determined? - What is the problem of imputation? - What is marginal (physical) product? What is average (physical) product? - What are returns to scale? How are they different from economies of scale? - How does the assumption of competitive markets affect the answer to many of these questions? - What is “product exhaustion?” - Is there a moral connation of factors of production being paid their marginal products? ## Slides Below, you can find the slides in two formats. Clicking the image will bring you to the html version of the slides in a new tab. The lower button will allow you to download a PDF version of the slides. ::: callout-tip You can type h to see a special list of viewing options, and type o for an outline view of all the slides. ::: I suggest printing the slides beforehand and using them to take additional notes in class (*not everything* is in the slides)!
